WHO? Roman Pavlyuchenko has signed for a club that doesn’t even have a Wikipedia page

https://www.dreamteamfc.com/c/transfers/223718/roman-pavlyuchenko-fc-ararat-moscow/

Remember Roman Pavlyuchenko, Spurs fans?

The forward was a staple of Tottenham’s forward-line between 2008-2011, but is seemingly winding down his career in the lower-reaches of Russian football.


Ah, the good ol’ days, when Spurs had Harry Redknapp and mediocre strikers

Since leaving North London at the end of the 2010-11 season, Pavlyuchenko has turned out for a handful of relatively well-known clubs, such as Lokomotiv Moscow, Kuban Krasnodar and Ural.

The 35-year-old has been a free-agent since leaving Ural at the end of last season, but has reportedly joined up with third-tier hopefuls FC Ararat Moscow.

Haven’t heard of them?

That’s because they didn’t exist a year ago.

They don’t even have a Wikipedia page – we already checked.



According to sports.ru, Pavlyuchenko has joined the new Moscow-based club on a one-year deal.

The club only recently passed their Russian FA license, and will play in the second division (the equivalent to League One, we assume) next season.

We couldn’t find out too much more about the club, but the name “Ararat” is reportedly in honour of the Armenian club Ararat Yerevan, who won the USSR championship in 1973.

They also play in orange, which is nice.

<ins>Newcastle due second payment on Moussa Sissoko - and will get £30million in full even if he moves</ins>

There were claims when the transfer was agreed that the deal has been structured in a way in which Spurs would not have to pay the full £30million if he was sold before the end of his five-year Tottenham contract but Newcastle sources have said that is not the case. Spurs will have to cough up the full £30million – even if he is sold this summer.

The 19-year-old has been a revelation in his homeland this season when firing home nine goals and providing seven assists as Basaksehir pushed for the title.

Such form has not gone unnoticed in the Premier League with a host of clubs, including Tottenham said to be showing an interest in the youngster.

There has even been talk of Tottenham agreeing an £8million deal, but this has been denied by Under’s agent, Omer Koray Uzun, who says his client is going nowhere for now.

“There is no agreement right now with any club, there are several clubs from England, Germany and France scouting Under but no deal,” Uzun was quoted as saying by Turkish-Football.

Meanwhile, Basaksehir president Goksel Gumusdag has also moved quickly to dismiss the reports of an agreed deal.

WHO? Roman Pavlyuchenko has signed for a club that doesn’t even have a Wikipedia page

https://www.dreamteamfc.com/c/transfers/223718/roman-pavlyuchenko-fc-ararat-moscow/

Remember Roman Pavlyuchenko, Spurs fans?

The forward was a staple of Tottenham’s forward-line between 2008-2011, but is seemingly winding down his career in the lower-reaches of Russian football.


Ah, the good ol’ days, when Spurs had Harry Redknapp and mediocre strikers

Since leaving North London at the end of the 2010-11 season, Pavlyuchenko has turned out for a handful of relatively well-known clubs, such as Lokomotiv Moscow, Kuban Krasnodar and Ural.

The 35-year-old has been a free-agent since leaving Ural at the end of last season, but has reportedly joined up with third-tier hopefuls FC Ararat Moscow.

Haven’t heard of them?

That’s because they didn’t exist a year ago.

They don’t even have a Wikipedia page – we already checked.



According to sports.ru, Pavlyuchenko has joined the new Moscow-based club on a one-year deal.

The club only recently passed their Russian FA license, and will play in the second division (the equivalent to League One, we assume) next season.

We couldn’t find out too much more about the club, but the name “Ararat” is reportedly in honour of the Armenian club Ararat Yerevan, who won the USSR championship in 1973.

They also play in orange, which is nice.
